My opinion about the game overall:
If you were expecting a funny/punny review then you came to the wrong review. I decided to make an actual helpful/serious review for the game. Let me start off saying this is a really great game and is a real and serious game despite looking like a joke, back when I saw this game in Greenlight I laughed and gave it a vote expecting it to be a game that wouldn't even get to a full release, when it first came out my friend bought it so I went to his place and played it for a few hours, after playing it a few times I decided to buy i. Aas it got more and more updates it got better. A lot of people say the game is hard to play with a keyboard but I disagree, back when I first played the game I didn't have a controller so I played it with a keyboard, after a while, I got a controller, and the only thing that was hard about playing with a controller was that sometimes I got confused with the buttons' names, overall it's better with a controller. Awesome game, they really put a lot of work to it and listened to the community throughout the making of the game.
Cons and pros:
+Remappable keyboard controls
+Changable sensitivity
+Graphic options also pretty customizable
+Great graphics
+Great support from the devlopers of the game in issues you might run into
+Achievements
-Controls can take time to get used to
-New players can sometimes be annoyed by the game's challenge but that's pretty subjective
Gamemodes:

Story mode: At the beginning of each level you are presented with some sort of letter about an insane guy who's also the house owner, you finish reading it or skip it and you then spawn as a  piece of bread at the start of the level, at some levels you have extras you can add to yourself like jam and butter which have some side effects. You travel through the level possibly using various objects on the way to eventually get to the toaster or pan or whatever else you want to fry yourself on, in most levels there is more than one way to toast yourself. You get a grade based on your edibility, tastiness and possibly your time but I'm not sure about that, grades are from A++ from F(you only get f if you didn't finish the level). Story mode is overall challenging and my personal favorite. There are 8 levels in the story mode game mode.

Bagel Race: In this gamemode you spawn as a bagel in a different spawn than your spawn points at Story Mode, you need to run through the map using 3 and 4 keys(by default assuming you're using the keyboard) and the mouse and pass through checkpoints on the way to the end, you get a grade based on how fast you completed the race. There are 8 levels in the bagel race game mode. You have no edibility in this game mode.

Rampage: In this game mode you play as a baguette. In this mode your goal is to cause as much damage as possible to various objects around the level, the more damage you cause the better grade you are gonna get. You have multiplier for everytime you smash a few things at once. You have no edibility in this game mode. Rampage has 8 levels. You have a time limit at this game mode.

Cheese hunt: In this game mode you play as a crackbread. In this game mode you spawn as crackbread and start wandering around to find cheese and touch it so it sticks to you, as far as I know there are 5 pieces of cheese in each level. you lose ediblity by falling and/or hitting something too hard. You have no time limit in this game mode. There are 8 levels to Cheese Hunt.

Zero G(ravity): In this game mode you play as a slice of bread. This game mode is pretty much the same as the regular gamemode only there isn't gravity and you need to fly around with jets attached to you. I cannot explain the controls to this game mode as they are very complicated to explain, the main difference from the main game mode is that your grade is also based off the amount of fuel you've used up(You have infinite fuel, you use up fuel when you use your jets). You have edibility in this game mode, you lose ediblity when you touch the floor as far as I know. There is no time limit in this game mode. There are 8 levels to Zero G(ravity).

… I could go on. I won’t. But I could.



******************


Due to popular demand Ive decided to add a more ‘wholemeal’ first look review for people who like that sort of thing.

The game is essential qwop combined with the floor is lava. You navigate your slice of bread around various obstacles on a quest to get yourself nicely toasted (insert your own joke there).  Encountering dirty items reduces your edibility and therefore your overall score, whilst getting smothered in tasty tasty jam boosts it.

The game controls exactly how you would imagine it does. Each corner is assigned a different button which when pressed holds that edge in place apparently regardless of the surface/physics. The mouse or thumb stick flicks the bread around of can be used to nudge it around for precise movements. Practiced or naturally skilled will surely be able to cartwheel their way onto the leaderboards quickly whilst people starting out will ultimately spend more time flailing around like a dying Magicarp. Your main opponent is your own frustration.

If the play style is sounding very familiar that’s because it is. Anyone who has already played Surgeon Simulator or Octodad will immediately recognise the pattern of destruction and failure. This means that behind its freshly baked exterior the game is likely to become stale fairly quickly. Like its sister games there is a big potential for fun workshop content but ultimately you cannot judge a game on what could possibly be made by fans later on.

It is worth pointing out that it is an early access game, meaning that it is essentially unfinished, although this game does feel a lot more complete than most. It is very much playable with the exception of a few minor bugs. Enabling the gif record mode makes the game basically unplayable and the music always seems to be coming out of a random corner of the room.

I think overall most people will have already made a decision about this game, and whatever your thoughts they are probably correct. It’s ultimately a casual iPad-destined meme-maker but it clean fun and will give most people a few laughs for less than the price of an average cinema ticket. If flinging a slice of bread around for a few hours is the sort of thing that will brighten your day, then this is probably for you.

I started the day as a slice of bread. Not the end piece, because no one likes the end piece. No, I was the second slice in. I emerged from my loaf in glorious fashion, spreading my crumbs all over as I flew from what I once called home. This was the start of my journey.

I emerged in to a world of culinary decadence. To my left was Mt. Butter, and to my right was Jelly Valley. There were so many places to see, so many things to do. Life had finally begun.

I began my voyage to Toaster Kingdom by first heading for Mt. Butter. It was always a dream of mine to stand-atop the hills on Mt. Butter, and I did just that. I paraded to the top in mere seconds, only to slide down Mt. Butter and splash right in to Jelly Valley.

It was like a slip-n-slide of deliciousness.

I emerged from Jelly Valley covered from bread to toe, only to come to the edge of the world. I could see it all from here; the vast landscapes of Breadland, the hills of Crumbilina, but most of all, I could see Toaster Kingdom, and I knew my journey was far from over.

In a moment of serenity, I took a giant leap of faith, and I floated through space and time, in an absolute moment of glory. I didn't know what was waiting for me below, but I knew this was what had to be done.

Falling for what seemed an eternity, I thought this to be the end. Just then, something emerges below me, and I land softly on to a giant looking board with wheels. My savior.

I thanked it for saving me, and we bonded very quickly. It turns out, we are both heading to the same destination, and he agrees to let me travel on him. I hold on tight, and off we go. We travel through canyons, wastelands, hell, we even traveled through large ravines.

We're almost there.

We arrive at the Counter-Top Haven. The final stop before Toaster Kingdom. Just when we are in-reach of the Toaster Kingdom, my new friend informs me that he can go no further, for he is not capable of climbing. He entrusts me with a gift for King Toaster, a serum of sorts. He called it Maple Syrup. I am clueless what it would be used for, after-all the King is french. I don't understand what he would possibly do with such a thing. Nevertheless, I say thank you for everything, as a tear of jelly starts rolling down my face, and I start my ascent to reach the top of Counter-Top Haven.

It's a rough climb. It takes me about a minute or two, as I seem to be slipping and sliding all over the cliffs and peaks of this place. Maybe it's the jelly, maybe it's the butter, but all's I know is that I must persevere. I must make it to Toaster Kingdom.

I finally reach the top of Counter-Top Haven, and Toaster Kingdom and the Toaster King are in my line of sight. I flop towards them as fast as my nimble body can take me, battered and buttered and bruised. I reach the entrance to Toaster Kingdom. I can feel it now. I'm almost there. I only have to climb once more and I will have completed my first voyage.

With all the strength I can muster, I grip tightly on to the walls of Toaster Kingdom. I manage to hoist myself a-top this beautiful landscape. I'm here. I made it. The Toaster King is in sight. I just have to decend to the throne room, and I will have fulfilled my purpose in life.

Just as I am readying myself to decend towards the king, a gust of wind blows me off of the top of the kingdom. Down I fly, past Counter-Top Haven. Below I go, to the ends of the earth. No one to save me this time. I fall. I fall.

I land in the dirt.

Ruined.

I wither and die.

10 / 10. Would play again.

reviewText:
I wasn't here for the trip through early access, but coming into the launch version blind, my experience was one of endearment, gradually eclipsed by a roaring frustration. It's a lovely novel concept, the story (yes, there is one) is pretty good, and the level design ranges from open and flexible to linear and ♥♥♥♥ WHOEVER MADE THIS. Mercifully, there is a Super Guide equivalent to let you get through any level at the expense of a forced E rank, although even with that in place you can still be hard pressed to figure out how to toast yourself.

I realize that the game is fumblecore at its heart, but it often seems to demand just a bit too much for what you can feasibly do with its unique blend of A) the controls, B) the physics, and C) the camera. The controls in and of themselves are generally manageable, but when attempting to swing like Bread Tarzan across a string of 6 or so sunflowers and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cocking things are just flailing about as though in a typhoon because of arbitrary WACKY physics, the game just starts to fall apart. If you manage to smash open a jam jar to coat yourself, you can spend a full couple of minutes wrestling with all of the broken glass trying to actually make contact with the jam -- and once coated it can actually make movement much more challenging, to the point that you'll be unable to detach from a surface until you've swiveled the camera to an angle where the controls feel like cooperating, assuming the camera also cooperates and doesn't get stuck inside a wall pointing at the ceiling. When levels last upwards of 10 minutes and have no checkpoints, getting dicked to death by the camera and/or how it interacts with the controls is not a fun experience. The epilogue took me 5 tries alone; once because it was my fault, three times in a row because the physics made my bread clip into the car and spaz out, the third time ending with me launching into space at infinite velocity.

There's only a handful of levels in total but a few different modes to play them in and a standing possibility of more post-release content for free and/or as DLC. All in all I enjoyed it, but the physics and camera still definitely need work, and due to the prolonged format of the levels as compared to Surgeon Simulator, it's just a much more frustrating experience as a whole.

As a final caveat, none of the achievements seem to work yet either.

reviewText:
There's challenging gameplay, there's unforgiving difficulty, and there's broken clumsy controls. The challenge in I am Bread doesn't come from the gameplay, or the missions, or the success conditions, but instead from fighting with the controller to do what you want it to do. If the player fails it should be due to his or her actions, not because the game decides to work against their inputs.

The humour of the game wears off quickly and it isn't enough to carry the frustration that comes from the core gameplay. Rampage mode is a nice option and serves as pure catharsis. I would actually be more interested in playing a fully-fleshed out Katamari Damacy style game with the rampage mechanics.

Overall, probably worth a try but I wouldn't pay full sticker price.

so far the game seems like a challenging one, and with my desire for challenge, this game was a good purchase. I am Bread has not yet gone stale, and I feel I could enjoy it for flours on end. It is enjoyable for me not only because of the challenge, but there is the fun appeal of being a bread, I'm not sure why but I feel as though I have always wanted to play as bread in a game. Luckily this isn't any sort of fake game like goat simulator, and I am excited to see what kinds of updates that could be in the future. The resolution settings are customizable like most games in case if the bread starts to look too grainy, and if you just barley make it to the toaster, but hit the ground, you have to wait until the next growing season.by playing this game I have reaped the rewards of being entertained and have recieved a hunger for bread.

Even if this game doesn't become the best or come out fully cooked, it plows the way for more innovative game designs. reviewText:
I am Bread is a third Steam game by Bossa Studios who are known thanks to their crazy Surgeon Simulator. If you've already seen (or played) the game, you know it challenges players by having difficult controls that makes it frustrating but also hilarious to play. In this case, they did it in pretty similar way, with important difference: You will be in control of a slice of bread that wants to get toasted. reviewText:
BUY/SALE/PASS:  Sale - Wait for a sale price

About ten years ago, there came along a budget title out of Japan named Katamari Damacy.  In the tiny feet of a diminutive prince, players were tasked with picking up whatever random crap was strewn around a room/house/neighborhood/city/planet as fast as you can.  It was strange, yet strangely compelling; an oddity of video games that came out of nowhere and has since been milked dry as a concept; even the original creator has distanced himself from the series.  Weird games slowly drift by the wayside as video games break way into the mainstream, and things become normal.

Then, in 2015, players were tasked with playing as a slice of bread.

Bossa Studios, the creators of Surgeon Simulator 2013, bring us yet another bizarro creation.  As a single slice of bread, your mission in I am Bread is to get toasted by any means necessary.  Gripping the surfaces and objects around you with the corners of your bread slice (somehow…), you must traverse the various rooms of a house to find that sweet embrace of heat that will get you nice and crispy.  But don’t land anywhere gross or linty!  Otherwise you’ll end up inedible, and what will even be the point of being toasted?  The horror of such a thought!

I am Bread is utter nonsense baked into a bizarre, fluffy bun.  Yet the gameplay is so fun and goofy, oftentimes creating some of the best accidentally funniest moments of any game released this year.  Purposefully frustrating controls leave the player pulling out their hair one moment and laughing the next.  There’s no escaping it.  You are bread.  And you will be toast, one way or another.  Delightful music, fun gameplay, funky concept, all worthy of a sale price purchase.

Good, silly experiences are hard to come by. Most end up just being one trick ponies and gimmick-a-thons. And the few decent ones end up being more like physics toys than actual games (Looking at you Turbo Dismount).

I am Bread turns out to be an actual GAME rather than a toy. It's challenging, strategic and most importantly fun to play.

The game is rather short. Right now there are 4 levels, each of which you could beat in 5 minutes (you won't, but you could). It took me 3 hours to complete. Might take a little longer if you choose to explore more.
Most levels have alternate routes and if that's not enough you could just scoot along the ceiling.

I've seen people complain about the controls, and I admit, the keyboard controls are pretty horrofic, so I suggest you use a controller. Learning and mastering the controls is the main challenge.
You start out clumsily flopping around, smashing everything your way. And by the end you'll be making flips from wall to wall like a preschooler on acid.

Cons mostly consist of some unwarranted failures due to wonky physics knocking over a toaster you desperately need. The learning curve is pretty harsh too. And the lack of real tutorial can be an issue if you get frustrated easily.

Overall. The game if real fun. It didn't feel samey and I can't wait for more to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Harder than Dark Souls ++++

Honestly, though, this game is hard to master. In fact, it's designed to be hard to master, just like its predecessor 'Surgeon Simulator'. The difference this time, though, is that you yourself are not in a fixed position. Also you are a slice of bread. This lends to some awkward hand-eye mishaps and equally awkward doughy propulsion. Eventually you get the hang of it and start cartwheeling and breadboarding all over the place. Once you figure out basic movement, you can conquor any environment. I have come to write this review shortly after beating all of the available campaign, and I plan on trying to get higher scores than straight Fs and Ds.

The health system of the game, I think, is actually great. It is 'Edibility', how appealing your spongy self looks. Seeming loosely based on the Five Second Rule, you can't spend too long touching the floor/rolling in ants or hair. This subsequently results in many restarts from mishaps in your yeastly yaw, which is also hilarious to watch. Who doesn't like watching a piece of bread fail at a highly unlikely adventure by spinning out of control across the room?

There's more than one way to slice a loaf. You can navigate through the room the way you decide, be it by skateboard, wall climbing, or by the 'easiest' path. With many different ways you can go, I am Bread is like an open world game. Just... open room. Swing from cabinets, smash the plates, hang off ledges: there's a whole bathroom of adventure out there!

With hope of more amazing content (and secrets), this game is worth every dime (and possibly penny). Definitely a must if on sale. It's truly a game, and not just a 'flop til you pop' gimmick.

This game is a crusted challenge. You will not succeed often. Persevere. One day you will be toast.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now that I've had a decent amount of time with the controls & have played through all 4 available levels I believe I can write my own take on the game. Note: I'm not great at this game, I have failed countless times. This is all based on my experience as someone playing this for fun & taking my time towards the goal.

I am Bread, from the makers of another favorite of mine Surgeon Simulator, leaves you in control of a slice of bread as you try to toast yourself by any means possible. I love the concept itself; it's silly, fun and frustrating beyond belief. It's more of a hit or miss if you'll like it. I'd suggest watching the game play and understanding that the controls are difficult and the game isn't completely serious before you buy it & suddenly find yourself upset because it's not perfect. It's Early Access & the developers are still adding a lot to this so I'm pretty content with what we have so far, though there's still a long way to go. *This means go to the Discussions and make suggestions, not whine over not besting the controls in 20 minutes* With that said...

Pros:
- You are bread
- You can roll in jam & butter to aid you in your goal
- Be creative! There are other ways to heat bread other than a toaster, have fun with it.
- A short narrative that follows our destructive path.
- You can crawl in cereal or other things.
- Make your heat source with destruction.
- Smash things.
- Take your time, have fun!
- Playing/Watching this over live broadcast with a group of friends is very entertaining.
- Procrastination simulator.

Cons:
- The controls are hard. I don't see any way of this being improved, to be honest. It takes time to get used to them but once you are it's more of a challenge of not touching the floor.
- The floor is lava.
- This guy's house is disgusting. There are some walls you can't touch without dying if you don't respond fast enough. The carpet is not always so forgiving depending where you land.
- The grip meter is necessary but it goes from fun to frustrating when you spend all that time climbing but you miss a beat & drop onto the nasty carpet again.
- The timer. I beat a level in 5 minutes without soiling my bread & I made a D at best. Unless you're hardcore going for that heat source I wouldn't expect a great rating.
- The camra angles.
- ^ I stepped on hair & couldn't see it at first.
- He's worried about bread wrecking his house yet he has garbage/germs littered everywhere. Why did you even leave the loaf out.
- I have a hard time removing the top concealing the butter.
- Please make the counters less edgy" in some aspects. I realize desks & the like have an edge sticking out on top but at times it's nearly impossible for me to get over that tiny lump.

Possible Bugs:
- I can't seem to lift myself up vertically with 3 & 4 anymore the way I do with 1 & 2.
- After flinging myself along the wall I can only grip again with maybe 1 or 2 keys or my bread won't grip at all.
- On the bathroom level I always drop down & end up grasping the toothpaste. This causes it to spasm in all directions and nearly send me flying.

Possible suggestions could go on forever so I'll just leave it at this. Enjoy bread simulator & if you're thinking about whining instead of a "this is why I don't like/recommend this game
date: turn off your computer & walk away. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has been fully released now s I thought it best to update my review.
Still virtually unplayable with the controls it has. Moving around is beyond silly. What makes it worse is the lag in controls as well.  I'm running a i7 and this game still has delays within the control system.
Graphics are mediocre at best. (And this is final version?)
There IS a goal of trying to toast yourself. Exciting.
Anyway, if you hit the floor you die very quickly.
Move on other objects and they smash.
Not sure if I am meant to smash all the objects or what but that seems the high point of gameplay.
Its general control has improved slightly since alpha, BUT there is still virtually no control of the main player.  The bread apparently has suction cups on the corners but they only last a little while. You end up just flopping around and spinning in circles. Movement is based more on luck that skill.
Game itself seems aimed at either little children who may get a thrill out of flopping around like soggy bread, or those that may be easily amused (or those with child like mentallity.) There is no real purpose to the levels or real storyline.
I gather its meant to be a bit of a joke type game but really the gameplay is the joke.
The developers seem to have had enough of the game, and released it as Final" rather than fix up the bugs

reviewText:
I Am Bread I guess would best be defined as a puzzle/adventure game, for it certainly has aspects of both genres. You may or may not like this game. If you're like me, you brought the game because of the interesting title name and backstory.

That said backstory is that you literally play as bread. You are some guy's bread, and you need to move around his house haphazardly in order to 'toast' yourself. I thought this title would be worth a look, so I went ahead and brought it, and soon found out that this was a hard game.

I'm not opposed to challenge. Some of the best games of all times were also the hardest. Challenge however shouldn't come in the form of bad camera angles and shoddy controls.

The idea behind I am bread is interesting, but once the novelty wears off, you'll probably find the game to be lackluster. Spending ages climbing up a fridge only to have you work undone by the punishing game mechanics isn't fun. It's tedious and boring. And once you get to the top of the fridge, you have to  proceed down a linear path in order to climb the next obstacle.

Ultimately, my point is this. You are apiece of bread which climbs things. There are literally only three or four game play elements that provide challenge. These game play elements are nothing new or exciting, and certainly not worth the price of this game.

If you can get it on sale, it might be worth a try. As it stands however, I Am Bread leaves a lot to be desired with me. This could have been an interesting game, but it is just so... boring, repetitive and tedious.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having completed the game (as much of it as there is) I can't wholly recommend it. It's definitely a nice curiosity, and it has some entertainment value - But it can also be very frustrating due to the unpredictable nature of the physics.

Obviously, getting used to it you'll get better at manoeuvering yourself around the environments, you'll still have difficulty executing an exact plan and making any fine adjustments. It's hard to imagine how they might improve the control system for mouse and keyboard, but one remains hopeful.

The concept remains quite funny, and the bolt-on story serves to amuse as you progress, as well as give reason to the increasingly elaborate household gauntlets of various unpleasant substances strewn across your path.

In short, as the novelty goes I think I would recommend the game - However from a purely critical perspective of enjoying the game itself and the content that exists as of yet, I would say go for it if you're interested, but only cautiously.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FBpW1EDTwgY

Full text w/ photos: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-i-am-bread/

Simulator games are in their hayday to be sure. There’s a simulator for everything you ever wanted to be, as well as games for a couple things you had no idea you wanted to be. I Am Bread has become the supreme frontrunner of the latter category in my book. The story is hysterical, told via psychiatrist statements about a man with rooms in his house being destroyed, and swearing that bread can move. The music is spot on, and the controls can take a lot of getting used to, but are completely fair. Made by Bossa Studios, it’s not a far throw from Surgeon Simulator, except that it features a wonderfully huge open world to explore, rather than just some dude’s chest cavity. You’ve been a goat, a deer, a gorilla, a farmer, a prisoner, a spaceman, and a rock. Now it’s finally time to pinch your inner loaf… Or something like that. Lets take a closer look at I Am Bread.

The first thing you’ll probably notice when you get into the game is the strange controls. Q,W,E,R (Or LT/LB RT/LB) are each assigned to a corner of your slice, pressing that button will cause the bread to grab, then you can fling yourself around using your mouse or control stick.  It sounds so simple, but much pain went into perfecting its execution… I’d say it was almost an hour before I became the ninja-bread man I never knew I longed to be. Once you finally stop nudging your bread along like Granny Gumgums, the music starts to click. It’s jazzy and quick and it makes my wall-crawling bread feel like he’s truly on the most dramatic adventure of his life. Hell, it probably is. It’s just a slice of bread after all.

Once you’ve mastered your abilities, you must complete the mission of getting toasted. Some lowly peons will tell you to use a toaster. Poppycock! I say find the nearest blow-dryer and just do what comes most natural. You also must stay off the floor, and away from gross stuff like trash and dishwater, as it will deplete your edibility bar. Once bread is no longer edible, it’s dead. Dead bread. The world is amazingly interactive. Almost everything can be broken or flung across the room via wonky physics, with delightful results! There is only one puzzle, “How can I become toast?”, but the answers are multiple, and as creative as you care to make them.

Now the ugly. The game does crash quite a bit… Which made recording at any length a bit frustrating. The controls are strange, but it’s likely on purpose, to increase the wackiness. That doesn’t do much for the extreme difficulty spike between the first level and the second, but there is time to adjust that as well. I also have to point out that the hardest part is wiggling yourself into the toaster. It caused me SO much heartache… You finally get to the toaster, only to discover that the real struggle has just begun. Overall though, I had a lot of fun with this game, and will likely return to it in the future. The environments are varied, and the freedom to solve a puzzle by riding on a rocket or skateboard, or simply scooting along the rug in a pot amuses me to no end.

Summary: A zany bread-simulator game with an open world and loads of freedom.

Final Score: 7/10 for gameplay, physics, and replayability. 9/10 with smaller difficulty curve.
